com.jefflunt.pedestrians
Class Pedestrian

java.lang.Object
  org.newdawn.slick.geom.Shape
      org.newdawn.slick.geom.Ellipse
          org.newdawn.slick.geom.Circle
              com.jefflunt.pedestrians.Pedestrian
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, org.newdawn.slick.Renderable, org.newdawn.slick.util.pathfinding.Mover
public class Pedestrian
extends org.newdawn.slick.geom.Circle
implements org.newdawn.slick.Renderable, org.newdawn.slick.util.pathfinding.Mover

A class describing a Pedestrian that moves around the world.

getTargetPathIndex

public int getTargetPathIndex()
Gets the index of the next point in the Path that this Pedestrian if following. That is, when a Pedestrian is following a Path, that Path is made up of many waypoints from the beginning to the end. As the Pedestrian traverses that that it moves from waypoint to waypoint, until it reaches the end of the Path. The index is zero-based, so if the Pedestrian is currently heading toward the 17th waypoint in its Path, then this method will return 16.

Returns:
the index of the next point along this Pedestrian's path.

getNumberOfPointsInPath

public int getNumberOfPointsInPath()
Gets the total number of points in the Path that this Pedestrian is following.

Returns:
the total number of points in this Pedestrian's path.

move

public void move(long timeSlice)
Causes the Pedestrian to move an appropriate amount, toward their target location, based on how much time has passed.

Parameters:
timeSlice - The amount of time that has elapsed, in milliseconds.

getCoordinatesOfCurrentBlock

public java.awt.Point getCoordinatesOfCurrentBlock()
Gets the (x, y) coordinate of the block that this Pedestrian currently occupies.

Returns:
a Point, containing the (x, y) coordinates of the tile in which this Pedestrian currently resides.

distanceToEndOfPath

public float distanceToEndOfPath()
The distance, from the Pedestrian's current location, along the Path they are following, to the end of the Path. It should be noted that this is an approximation. Due to various Pedestrian behaviors (such as collision avoidance), it's very possible that the actual Path the Pedestrian takes may be slightly modified from it's planned Path. If the Pedestrian doesn't run into anything they need to avoid along their Path, then the value returned from this method is going to be extremely accurate, to within a fraction of a single pixel. In a heavily populated area where the Pedestrian must avoid collisions, and other movement modifiers may apply, this method can only provide an approximation at best. Finally, if a Pedestrian is not currently following a Path, then this method will return 0.0.

Returns:
The distance from the Pedestrian's current location, along their Path, to the end of the Path.

isOnAPathSomewhere

public boolean isOnAPathSomewhere()
Whether or not the Pedestrian has reached the end of their Path.

Returns:
true if the Pedestrian is currently on a Path somewhere (even if their current speed is zero). False otherwise.

Parameters:

distanceToTarget

public float distanceToTarget()
The distance, from the Pedestrian's current location, to their current target location. If this Pedestrian is following a Path, then this method returns how far it is to the next point in the path only. If you want to find out how far the Pedestrian has yet to go along their Path, see distanceToEndOfPath.

Returns:
The distance between the Pedestrian's current location, and their target point.
See Also:
distanceToEndOfPath

distanceToPoint

public float distanceToPoint(float x,
                             float y)
The distance, directly from the Pedestrian's current location, to the (x, y) point specified.

Parameters:
x - the x-coordinate of the point
y - the y-coordinate of the point
Returns:
the distance from the Pedestrian's current location to the specified point.

hasReachedDestination

public boolean hasReachedDestination()
Whether or not the Pedestrian has reached the (x, y) location they are currently heading for.

Returns:
true if they've reached that destination, false otherwise. If you ask a Pedestrian to follow a Path, this method is used internally to know when the Pedestrian arrives at each of the points along that Path, and serves as a way to know when the Pedestrian should change direction and head for the next point on that Path.

stop

public void stop()
Causes the Pedestrian to stop, and forget where they were headed.

See Also:
pause, resume

changeSpeedTo

public void changeSpeedTo(float speed)
Changes the Pedestrian's speed, but does not change their destination. If the Pedestrian has already arrived at their destination, then this method will have no effect.

Parameters:
speed - the speed at which you desire them to get there (e.g. "Post haste!").

                       float y,
                       float speed)
Sends this Pedestrian from their current location, directly toward the specified point in space.

Parameters:
x - the x-coordinate of the destination
y - the y-coordinate of the destination
speed - the speed at which to travel there.

headDirection

public void headDirection(int upDownLeftOrRight,
                          float speed)
Sets the Pedestrian in motion either up, down, left, or right. The Pedestrian's target location is actually set to Float.MAX_VALUE or -Float.MAX_VALUE, depending on which way you tell them to go. They will continue in that direction unless blocked by something, until they literally reach the edge of the world, where they will stop. It should also be noted that an assumption about direction has been made. It is assumed that "UP" is going to move you up along a computer screen, since it's assumed that you will be displaying Pedestrians on a screen of some sort. Coordinate systems on a computer screen usually have their y-axis increasing DOWNWARD, whereas the coordinate systems you learned about in school have their y-axis increasing UPWARD. 
 Your typical coordinate system:          Your computer screen's coordinate system:
 
                  +y  (up)                               ((-Y))  (up)
                 / \                                      / \
                  |                                        |
                  |                                        |
 (left) -x  <-----+-----> +x (right)      (left) -x  <-----+-----> +x (right)
                  |                                        |
                  |                                        |
                  |                                        |
                 \ /                                      \ /
                  -y  (down)                             ((+Y)) (down)
That's it. No big deal, but it might save you some trouble one day.

Parameters:
upDownLeftOrRight - the direction you want this Pedestrian to go.
speed - the speed at which you desire the Pedestrian to travel.
See Also:
ConfigValues.UP, DOWN, LEFT, and RIGHT.

getDirection

public float getDirection()
Gets the direction of travel of this Pedestrian, measured in radians.

Returns:
the direction of travel, in radians.

getDirectionToTarget

public float getDirectionToTarget()
Gets the direction from this Pedestrian's current location, toward their target location.

Returns:
the direction, measured in radians, from the Pedestrian to their target location.

getPrimaryDirection

public int getPrimaryDirection()
Returns the primary direction that this pedestrian is heading in. It is not necessary that a Pedestrian be heading precisely in that direction. This method is simply supposed to tell you something like, "They're basically heading to the right." or "They're basically heading up, and to the right", etc.

Returns:
one of UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT, UP_LEFT, UP_RIGHT, DOWN_LEFT, DOWN_RIGHT

getSpeed

public float getSpeed()
Gets this Pedestrian's current speed.

Returns:
this Pedestrian's current speed.
